text:
What the heck is going on here?

```julia> c
3×3 SparseMatrixCSC{Int64, Int64} with 3 stored entries:
 ⋅  ⋅  1
 ⋅  1  ⋅
 1  ⋅  ⋅

julia> c ./ 1
3×3 SparseMatrixCSC{Float64, Int64} with 3 stored entries:
  ⋅    ⋅   1.0
  ⋅   1.0   ⋅
 1.0   ⋅    ⋅

julia> c ./ [1 1 1]
3×3 SparseMatrixCSC{Float64, Int64} with 9 stored entries:
 0.0  0.0  1.0
 0.0  1.0  0.0
 1.0  0.0  0.0```

elements.text: What the heck is going on here?

julia> c
3×3 SparseMatrixCSC{Int64, Int64} with 3 stored entries:
 ⋅  ⋅  1
 ⋅  1  ⋅
 1  ⋅  ⋅

julia> c ./ 1
3×3 SparseMatrixCSC{Float64, Int64} with 3 stored entries:
  ⋅    ⋅   1.0
  ⋅   1.0   ⋅
 1.0   ⋅    ⋅

julia> c ./ [1 1 1]
3×3 SparseMatrixCSC{Float64, Int64} with 9 stored entries:
 0.0  0.0  1.0
 0.0  1.0  0.0
 1.0  0.0  0.0

text: `c./1` makes sense. `Int/Int=Float`

elements.text: makes sense.
Int/Int=Float

text: The other one also makes sense. the inverse of an arbitrary sparse matrix will usually be dense. Did you want `c=Diagonal(c)`?

elements.text: The other one also makes sense. the inverse of an arbitrary sparse matrix will usually be dense. Did you want
c=Diagonal(c)

julia> sp ./ sum(sp, dims=1)

 1.0  0.0  0.5

julia> sp .* begin inv.(sum(sp, dims=1)) end

 1.0   ⋅   0.5```

text: :wat:
Your example is the confusing one. Mine is a guess that `*` might be special-cased, while generic broadcasting gives you the full matrix.

might be special-cased, while generic broadcasting gives you the full matrix.
